comment_body: @saiarcot895 fyi

Please follow [*How to Write a Git Commit Message*](https://chris.beams.io/posts/git-commit/) and improve *Ported patch to 5.10.40 kernel* (imperative mood, and say what patch).

> When switch from Linux 4.19.x to 5.10.40 the patch was disabled, as it did not apply cleanly. Forward port it to Linux 5.10.40 and add it to the Linux 5.10 patch series. Tested on ….

PS: How is the upstreaming effort of Cisco patches going?
@saiarcot895 fyi
In the merge/pull request description, please mark up the text using (GitHub) Markdown. You can either indent the terminal paste by four spaces, or enclose them in \`\`\`/\`\`\`.

Please note in the patch file, that this patch was applied to Linux 5.14 in [commit 4e5418f787 (hwmon: (pmbus_core) Check adapter PEC support)](https://git.kernel.org/pub/scm/linux/kernel/git/torvalds/linux.git/commit/?id=4e5418f787ec56d7fe3c6efee486b8f508c58baf).

The summary *Review comments incorporated to add kernel support for patch* is too unspecific. Please amend it. Maybe:

> cisco-hwmon-pmbus_core-pec-support-check: Document upstream Linux 5.14 inclusion

Also add *cisco-hwmon-pmbus_core-pec-support-check* to the commit message summary of the first patch.

PS: Please make sure, that reading `git log --oneline` gives already a good picture, on what is happening in the commits.

[![CLA assistant check](https://cla.opensource.microsoft.com/pull/badge/signed)](https://cla.opensource.microsoft.com/Azure/sonic-linux-kernel?pullRequest=246)
All CLA requirements met.
@donboll kindly review the change.
Maybe rename the file `disable-building-linux-source.patch` to `disable-building-linux-source-deb-package.patch`.
Makes sense. Renamed the patch.
/azp run
Azure Pipelines successfully started running 1 pipeline(s).
@saiarcot895 , do you know why the pr build failure?

arm64 container image is getting pulled somehow, instead of amd64. Not sure why.

https://dev.azure.com/mssonic/build/_build/results?buildId=46722&view=logs&j=83516c17-6666-5250-abde-63983ce72a49&t=c7f250fc-f82c-4943-9630-34887e724e3a&l=286

I hadn't enabled the [daily pipeline to build the bullseye slave image ](https://dev.azure.com/mssonic/build/_build?definitionId=215). I just enabled it now and will trigger a run. I wonder if your pipeline which built the arm64 image and updated the latest tag removed the one for amd64, and so arm64 was the only arch image that was available with the latest tag.

Can you elaborate, why this file is added, that means, what concerns/problems are addressed? Using GitHub’s watch function notifies oneself about merge/pull requests and issues.

Also, please note in the commit message, who @saiarcot895 is, and maybe in what team they work.

> Can you elaborate, why this file is added, that means, what concerns/problems are addressed? Using GitHub’s watch function notifies oneself about merge/pull requests and issues.
> 
> Also, please note in the commit message, who @saiarcot895 is, and maybe in what team they work.

@paulmenzel this is an automated assign mechanism to assign all PRs to Saikrishna by default.

> @paulmenzel this is an automated assign mechanism to assign all PRs to Saikrishna by default.

Yes, I figured. But until now I thought, that Guohan is taking care of this repository. So some sentence like below would be helpful.

> Saikrishna joined Guohan’s team and has been working on the 5.10 port. He is going to take over merge/pull request review, so assign all merge/pull requests to him automaticallly.
i created a sonic-kernel team for better management.

> Upstream: https://git.kernel.org/pub/scm/linux/kernel/git/groeck/linux-staging.git/commit/?h=hwmon-next&id=e8ac01e5db329cf4ac2b36ef66b9d877330a990c

That is not in Linus’ master branch yet, is it? Maybe give some more background, and also say, that you not only take that one commit, but the state of the driver files from that commit?

> > Upstream: https://git.kernel.org/pub/scm/linux/kernel/git/groeck/linux-staging.git/commit/?h=hwmon-next&id=e8ac01e5db329cf4ac2b36ef66b9d877330a990c
> 
> That is not in Linus’ master branch yet, is it? Maybe give some more background, and also say, that you not only take that one commit, but the state of the driver files from that commit?

Yes, this commit is currently added in hwmon-next branch and is not yet available in Linus's master branch.
This single commit adds the max6620 driver (previously not available in upstream)

  Enable vDSO for 32-bit applications (COMPAT_VDSO) [Y/n/?] (NEW)

@lguohan would you please take a look?
how is this efforts related to 5.10?

> how is this efforts related to 5.10?

Hi @lguohan, for each hw-mgmt release, we have separated sets of kernel patches for different kernel versions. These new patches are for 4.19, if they are also relevant to 5.10, there will be also patches in the hw-mgmt 5.10 patch list. 
Currently, for 5.10 upgrading we are taking all the patches from the hw-mgmt 5.10 patch list(for upgrading to 5.10 we are using a newer hw-mgmt release, which will including more kernel patches),  so no need to rebase these new patches when upgrading to 5.10.
can we wait till 5.10 kernel being merged for these pr?

> can we wait till 5.10 kernel being merged for these pr?

Hi Guohan, prefer to have this merged earlier,  it's including some bug fix and also we have a feature that has a dependency on this new hw-mgmt package, we want that feature to go public as earlier as possible.

Nit:

> regression tests have been performed against these patches on the Mellanox platform, no issue found

Please make that a sentence, starting with a capital letter, and adding a dot/period at the end.

Please mention, that the patch was added to Linux 5.5, and the LTS series it was added to are 5.4.3 and 4.19.89). SONiC’s Linux kernel is currently based on 4.19.152.

Also, it’s unclear to me, why the build bot (CI) succeeded.
The CI build passed because the old patch is incorrect. Before applying the old patch, the fix is already in thermal_core.c; after applying the old patch, the fix is removed from thermal_core.c.
@paulmenzel could you please review this again?

> The CI build passed because the old patch is incorrect. Before applying the old patch, the fix is already in thermal_core.c; after applying the old patch, the fix is removed from thermal_core.c.

Excuse my ignorance. I do not understand. The old actually reverts the correct patch?

I screwed up my suggested sentence:

> The patch was added to Linux 5.5, and the LTS series it was added to are 5.4.3 and 4.19.89). SONiC’s Linux kernel is currently based on 4.19.152.

The patch was added to Linux 5.5, and the LTS series in 4.19.89 and 5.4.3. …

Hi @paulmenzel , the old patch is wrong, it reverts or breaks the correct code.

Here is the correct patch content: https://github.com/torvalds/linux/commit/163b00c , you can compare it with sonic kernel code or early 4.19 code here https://github.com/torvalds/linux/blob/v4.19/drivers/thermal/thermal_core.c, the correct fix is already there, we don't need any patch, so i created this PR to remove the old one.
@paulmenzel could you please review this again?

I am confused by below statement

> Here is the correct patch content: https://github.com/torvalds/linux/commit/163b00c , you can compare it with sonic kernel code or early 4.19 code here https://github.com/torvalds/linux/blob/v4.19/drivers/thermal/thermal_core.c

Checking the 4.19 code, it already contains the first part of the patch
```
cancel_delayed_work(&tz->poll_queue);
```

But it does not contains the second part of the patch
```
cancel_delayed_work_sync(&tz->poll_queue);
```

And I also has the same worry, if a patch does not work as expected, why build pass? This is not to blame you, but trying to understand what is missing in the patching process.

And here is 4.19.152 commit: https://github.com/torvalds/linux/commit/ad326970d25cc85128cd22d62398751ad072efff. 

> And I also has the same worry, if a patch does not work as expected, why build pass? This is not to blame you, but trying to understand what is missing in the patching process.

For this issue, guess there was some mistake has been made while generating the patch. Instead of applying the fix to the code, it's generated in a opposite way, the content of the wrong patch is reverting the first part of the patch, so it can still building but make the fix incomplete.

@lguohan and @daall can you please cherry pick to 202012?
why is 0072 is needed? i thought we have disabled thermal zone on this branch?
0076 is a new feature, why do we need it on 201911 branch?

> why is 0072 is needed? i thought we have disabled thermal zone on this branch?

In order to use kernel thermal control algorithm, thermalctld will enable thermal zone when it starts.

> 0076 is a new feature, why do we need it on 201911 branch?

Hi Guohan, this new sensor support is required by the MSN4700 A1 system, we also planned to support it in 201911.

> > why is 0072 is needed? i thought we have disabled thermal zone on this branch?
> 
> In order to use kernel thermal control algorithm, thermalctld will enable thermal zone when it starts.

added on top of Junchao's feedback:  it is NOT that the thermal zone is altogether disabled, what was disabled is the critical trip points to avoid the shutting down of zones by the thermal zone mechanism ,  but beside that the mechanism is still there and provides indications, such as warnings of changing temperatures etc. this patch is a common fix for the thermal zone  mechanism,  so it still valuable to backport it.

> Please contact the [Linux kernel PMBUS maintainers](https://git.kernel.org/pub/scm/linux/kernel/git/torvalds/linux.git/tree/MAINTAINERS#n14233), why the generic driver does not work.

From the pmbus driver https://elixir.bootlin.com/linux/v4.19.152/source/drivers/hwmon/pmbus/pmbus.c#L148
The pmbus driver does not support the chip that uses direct mode yet.
This driver supports dps200 which uses coefficients defined in the datasheet.

From: Saranpong Chgobtrong <schobtr@celestica.com>

[…]

Thank you for the patch.

1.  Ingetrate → Integrate
2.  Please add more details, where the patch comes from. Best you give the git commit hash from the patch in Linus’ master branch.
3.  Please elaborate, what the problem is and how the patch was tested. (Most could be taken from the patch description I guess.)

> Thank you for the patch.
> 
> 1. Ingetrate → Integrate
> 2. Please add more details, where the patch comes from. Best you give the git commit hash from the patch in Linus’ master branch.
> 3. Please elaborate, what the problem is and how the patch was tested. (Most could be taken from the patch description I guess.)

This is a work in progress in term of linux main. Our team will do the upstream process soon but this must not delay this update. The reason for that that this is a real production issue and we cannot wait for this one.

As for the information you are looking for, it is all in the patch itself.

"
Disable software thermal protection by removing critical trip points
for the all thermal zones.

According to the system requirements software should never perform
system thermal protection, since all the systems implement two levels
of thermal protection: the first one is performed by firmware, the
second, in case firmware was not able to perform protection, by
hardware, while the temperature threshold for hardware protection is
higher than for firmware.

In both cases, when critical temperature is reached, system will be
shutdown.
"

This is relevant to only Mellanox switches as the main protection is done by Firmware.

The commit in this merge/pull request still has the typos and a to-be-desired commit message. It’s rude to expect from reviewers and later people looking through commits to look at the diff to find out what is done.

If this is important to you, then I suggest you make sure, that all the formal requirements for patches are met.

For upstream, if it’s done later, please add a comment to the commit message, that it is going to be upstreamed soon.

> The commit in this merge/pull request still has the typos and a to-be-desired commit message. It’s rude to expect from reviewers and later people looking through commits to look at the diff to find out what is done.
> 
> If this is important to you, then I suggest you make sure, that all the formal requirements for patches are met.
> 
> For upstream, if it’s done later, please add a comment to the commit message, that it is going to be upstreamed soon.

Thank you for the patch.

1. Why can `patch/driver-hwmon-pmbus-dni_dps460-use-kstrtol-from-user.patch` be removed?
2. Could you please add the merge/pull request description also to the git commit message?
3. Please sign off the commit *and* `patch/driver-hwmon-pmbus-dni_dps460-update-pmbus-core.patch`.
4. Please send the patch to Linux upstream, so it does not need to be maintained in the future in here, but is maintained in upstream Linux.

Item 4 is very important in my opinion.
have the same question, @ArunSaravananBalachandran, can you address?

> Thank you for the patch.
> 
> 1. Why can `patch/driver-hwmon-pmbus-dni_dps460-use-kstrtol-from-user.patch` be removed?
> 2. Could you please add the merge/pull request description also to the git commit message?
> 3. Please sign off the commit _and_ `patch/driver-hwmon-pmbus-dni_dps460-update-pmbus-core.patch`.
> 4. Please send the patch to Linux upstream, so it does not need to be maintained in the future in here, but is maintained in upstream Linux.
> 
> Item 4 is very important in my opinion.


1. With `driver-hwmon-pmbus-dni_dps460-use-kstrtol-from-user.patch` introduced to avoid the crash seen in #152, write on the attribute fails with 'Bad address' error. 
```
root@sonic:/home/admin# echo 15000 > /sys/class/i2c-adapter/i2c-1/1-0059/fan1_target
bash: echo: write error: Bad address
root@sonic:/home/admin#
```
Updating the pmbus_data structure in ‘dni_dps460’ driver’s patch to the one used in latest kernel version, resolves the crash seen in both read Azure/sonic-buildimage#6140 and write #152 on the attribute and removing the `driver-hwmon-pmbus-dni_dps460-use-kstrtol-from-user.patch` resolves the 'Bad address' error.

2. Will amend the commit to update the commit message.
3. Will signoff the commit and the patch through a new commit.
4. The `dni_dps460` driver is defined only in sonic-linux-kernel via `patch/driver-hwmon-pmbus-dni_dps460.patch` and not available in upstream linux. Currently this driver is used only in Dell S6000 platform for accessing PSU attributes.

Thank you for your replies. Your explanation in item 1. is very good, and is perfect to have in a commit message, so people do not have to read the merge/pull request discussion.

Regarding 4., I know the driver is not in upstream Linux, but that is the goal, and nothing would prevent that. To avoid future porting work, it’d be great, if you sent the whole driver upstream, seeing that you also have access to the hardware.

On what device is this tested?

It’d be great, if you sent a backport request to stable@vger.kernel.org, so it gets added to the stable series.
tested here. https://github.com/Azure/sonic-buildimage/pull/6429

Thank you for the reference. Commits should still be self-contained, and people cannot be expected to crossreference commits or even repositories. It’d be great, if the Celestica DX010 would be mentioned here too.

Also, I really think a message to stable@vger.kernel.org with the backport request should be sent. (And soon SONiC should switch to Linux 5.10 anyway. ;-))
added the tested message.  those patches will be removed 5.2-rc1. I haven't sent patch to stable@vger.kernel.org before. let me see what needs to be done before send to that mailing list.
